definitions.definition: to fasten or join one thing to another

examples.text: I attach a copy of my notes for your information.
A copy of his document is attached as Appendix 3 at the end of this book.
Attach the coupon to the front of your letter.
They have **attached** a number of **conditions** to the agreement *(= said that the conditions must be part of the agreement)*

definitions.definition: to send an electronic document with an email

examples.text: I attach a copy of the spreadsheet.
I am attaching the image as a PDF file.

definitions.definition: to believe that something is important or worth thinking about
definitions.sensetop: attach importance, significance, value, weight to something

examples.text: I attach great importance to this research.
examples.contextForm: attach importance, significance, value, weight to something

examples.text: I wouldn't attach too much weight to these findings.

definitions.definition: to join somebody for a time, sometimes when you are not welcome or have not been invited

examples.text: He attached himself to me at the party and I couldn't get rid of him.

definitions.definition: to be connected with somebody/something; to connect something to something
definitions.sensetop: attach to somebody/somethingattach something to somebody/somethingbe attached to something

examples.text: No one is suggesting that any health risks attach to this product.
This does not attach any blame to you.
Nowadays, there is less **stigma attached to** mental illness than in the past.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘seize by legal authority’): from Old French atachier or estachier ‘fasten, fix’, based on an element of Germanic origin related to stake ‘post’; compare with attack.
